awd_titl_txt: Unveiling The Cosmic History of Light
awd_abstract_narration:
The light of all stars, galaxies, and accreting black holes in the observable Universe is encoded in the extragalactic background light (EBL), which is critically important to understand galaxy evolution and stellar activity, but as of today it remains still highly uncertain.  This project will provide the first measurements of the intensity and evolution of the UV-optical component of the EBL from the present age to the time when the Universe was only 1.5 billion years old.  The measurements provided by this project will be used to estimate the luminosity density of galaxies, quantify the extent of the population of ultra-faint galaxies, and measure the fraction of photons that escape absorption within the host galaxy and how that changes with redshift and wavelength.  This project will foster the partnership with historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs) to increase the number of African Americans that are awarded an MS in physics and support a graduate student who will complete his PhD with this award.
 
Gamma-ray photons emitted from distant sources can be absorbed in the interaction with photons of the EBL, thus providing an indirect tool to quantify the intensity of the EBL as a function of redshift.  This project will rely on all known gamma-ray sources to measure the intensity of the optical-UV component of the EBL, for the first time, up to a redshift of 4.  These measurements will allow the PI and his team to constrain the luminosity density of galaxies and investigate whether galaxies are responsible for the re-ionization of the Universe.

por.por_cntn:
The light of every star, galaxy and accreting black hole is encoded in the extragalactic background light (EBL), a diffuse uniform glow across the ultraviolet, optical, infrared wavebands. The EBL is of fundamental importance as it can reveal key information about the evolution of galaxies, stars and the expansion of our Universe. However, bright foreground emissions from our solar system and our Galaxy render the characterization of the EBL a nearly impossible task. 

 

In this project, we have used an indirect method to measure the EBL based on the propagation of gamma rays through the Universe. Indeed, on their way to Earth these photons can be absorbed in the interaction with EBL photons producing an electron-positron pair. This absorption can be observed in the spectra of distant gamma-ray sources and can be used to measure the EBL as a function of wavelength and lookback time. 

 

As part of this program, we have characterized the EBL-induced absorption in the spectra of >740 distant gamma-ray sources. This enabled the first determination of the EBL all the way to when the Universe was less than 1 billion years old. Moreover, this allowed us to:

-measure accurately the star-formation rate of the Universe as a function of lookback time

-place the strongest constraints on the UV emission from faint galaxies at the end of the re-ionization era.

 

Finally, we have successfully proved that the EBL can be used to constrain cosmological parameters like the matter density and expansion rate of the Universe.
